unittitle.value: Tamiment Library Collection of Noam Chomsky Correspondence and Other Materials Relating to the Faurisson Case

abstract.value: This collection contains material relating to a controversy surrounding Noam Chomsky's defense of the civil liberties of Professor Robert Faurisson, a French Holocaust revisionist.  Articles from the conservative Australian periodical <emph render="italic">Quadrant</emph> and an excerpt from the book <emph render="italic">Droit et Histoire</emph>, by Pierre Guillaume, address this episode, and are accompanied by copies of correspondence discussing Chomsky's opinions and actions.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Materials donated by George Glauberman, Werner Cohn and W. D. Rubinstein in 1994 and 1995. The accession number associated with this collection is 2009.091.

Robert Faurisson continues to express his views and, as recently as 2006, was given  a three-month suspended sentence by a Paris correctional court for denying the Holocaust on an Iranian television channel.
The remainder of the collection consists of copies of correspondence between Chomsky and each of the three professors -- Werner Cohn, George Glauberman and W. D. Rubinstein.
